title: 110_s2471
content: The "USERRA Enforcement Improvement Act of 2007" is the short title of the Act. It aims to reform the USERRA complaint process. The "USERRA Enforcement Improvement Act of 2007" amends section 4322 of title 38, United States Code, to expedite the investigation and resolution of complaints. It requires the Secretary to notify complainants of their rights within 5 days and provide technical assistance upon request. The "USERRA Enforcement Improvement Act of 2007" amends section 4322 of title 38, United States Code, to expedite complaint resolution. It requires the Secretary to complete actions on complaints within 90 days and refer complaints to the Attorney General within 15 days. The amendment to section 4324(a)(1) of title 38 requires the Secretary to refer complaints within 15 days of receiving a request. Additionally, section 4323(a) is amended to require the Attorney General to make a decision on representing the complainant within 45 days of receiving a referral. The amendment requires the Special Counsel to make a decision on representing the complainant within 45 days of receiving a referral and notify the person of the decision. SEC. 3. EXPANSION OF REPORTING REQUIREMENTS WITH RESPECT TO ENFORCEMENT OF USERRA. The Secretary of Defense will now provide an annual report on cases reviewed by the National Committee for Employer Support of the Guard and Reserve, including those involving the same individual seeking employment or reemployment. The Department of Defense will provide an annual report on cases reviewed by the National Committee for Employer Support of the Guard and Reserve, including those involving individuals seeking employment or reemployment, with a focus on disability-related issues. The Department of Defense will provide a quarterly report to Congress, the Secretary of Defense, the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, the Attorney General, and the Special Counsel. The report will detail cases where the Secretary did not meet certain requirements. The Department of Defense will provide a quarterly report to Congress, the Secretary of Defense, the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, the Attorney General, and the Special Counsel detailing cases where requirements were not met. This includes cases where referrals were not made within the required time periods. The Department of Defense will report cases where referrals under specific sections did not meet requirements to Congress, the Secretary of Defense, the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, the Attorney General, and the Special Counsel. Coordination will ensure uniform categorization of data in reports. The amendments ensure uniform categorization of information in reports and provide electronic access to case files for designated officials. Effective date applies to reports after enactment of the Act.
